Avete mai incontrato Galileo a Padova? E sapete che la prima stella cometa ‚Äúcon la coda‚Äù fu dipinta proprio a Padova da Giotto, nella celebre Cappella degli Scrovegni? Storie di stelle e pianeti, orologi e meridiane si nascondono nelle citt√†, sotto un portico, dentro a una chiesa, sulla facciata di un palazzo e ci raccontano quanto la conoscenza del cielo fosse importante per i nostri antenati. Il progetto ‚ÄúSeconda stella a destra‚Äù traccia un itinerario alla ricerca degli elementi celesti disseminati nel centro storico di Padova e permette di scoprire una citt√† non convenzionale, tra astronomia, arte e cultura. L‚Äôitinerario parte simbolicamente da Prato della Valle, ai piedi della statua di Galileo Galilei, che proprio a Padova fece delle scoperte che cambiarono profondamente la nostra conoscenza astronomica. Il percorso si snoda tra i luoghi del centro storico, dentro le mura, e si conclude alla Specola, sede dell‚ÄôOsservatorio astronomico di INAF ‚Äì Istituto Nazionale di Astrofisica. Vi porter√† a scoprire i luoghi di Galileo, dalla sede dell‚ÄôUniversit√† in cui insegnava alla sua casa, i luoghi del tempo, come meridiane e orologi, e i luoghi del cielo, raffigurazioni cio√® di volte stellate, simboli celesti, stemmi. Potrete seguire l‚Äôitinerario per intero, scegliere un‚Äôesplorazione tematica o, ancora, creare il vostro percorso, saltando qua e l√†. L‚Äôimportante √® che ricordiate una cosa: di alzare gli occhi al cielo!

Eyes toward the sky and arm pointing at something up there: have you ever met Galileo Galilei in Padua? You will find him in the spectacular Prato della Valle, where he appears as one of the 78 statues of illustrious people that decorate the largest square of the city (maybe the largest in Europe!). The ‚ÄúPrato‚Äù, that‚Äôs what the locals call this square, although it actually has a elliptical shape and a green island at the centre. It‚Äôs in an area reclaimed from a swamp, which was drained at the end of the Eighteenth century. It has always been a lively place and it still hosts a busy market every Saturday.

For locals ‚Äùthe Saint‚Äù is Saint Anthony: they‚Äôll know who you mean. So universal and loved, he doesn‚Äôt even need to be named. Artists such as Giotto, Donatello, Mantegna and Giusto de‚ÄôMenabuoi have all left their mark on ‚Äúhis‚Äù grand Basilica over the centuries. Its domes, its cloisters and its works of art reveal stories of devotion, spirituality and beauty. Inside you‚Äôll find various starry vaults and outside a splendid sun on the entrance, a copy of the one by Mantegna, which you‚Äôll find inside the Basilica. It‚Äôs an ancient symbol for divinity.

Padua is the place where Galileo Galilei lived ‚Äúthe best eighteen years of my whole life‚Äù, teaching, studying and observing the sky. He lived in a street once called Borgo Vignali and later rechristened via Galileo Galilei. Apparently that‚Äôs the place where he discovered Jupiter‚Äôs satellites, a crucial moment in the birth of the modern scientific method. The house is not open to visitors, but there‚Äôs a plaque outside in memory of the scientist. For the rest, just free your imagination!

Almost hidden in a shadowy street, you will find this beautiful but neglected church, with 26 arches outside. Begun int he fifteenth century, it was once part of a great complex, including a convent, the first hospital in Padua, the charitable Scuola della Carit√† and the Oratorio di Santa Margherita. Inside the church, between an almost-secret garden and a canvas ascribed to Veronese, you will also find a plaque to Stella Stella, dedicated by his son.

One of the oldest churches in town, Santa Sofia‚Äôs character comes from the contrast between the elegant external structure and the great sparseness of the interior. Its inclined fa√ßade can be intimidating, but it‚Äôs worth visiting the church because inside you will find other traces of Galileo‚Äôs presence. At the end of the nave is baptismal font where Vincenzo, the scientist‚Äôs third and last son, was christened.

In the past, this street was one of the main thoroughfares of Padua, because it was near the main town canals, which are now filled with soil. The history and cultural richness of the area are evident in the surviving aristocratic palaces, the Pollini conservatory and the Centro Culturale Altinate. Together, they create a lively atmosphere, in which it is pleasant to stroll up to the porta Altinate. Just before you get there, you might notice a curious six pointed ‚Äùstar‚Äù represented on a shield. Some believe it is the symbol of an ancient urban district; others say it represents the wheel of a printing-press, in memory of the first family of publishers in town.

Known as the Chiesa degli Eremitani, the Church of the Hermits, because the old monastery attached to it (the current location of the Musei Civici) was a destination for pilgrims passing by. Reconstructed after being bombed in the Second World War, it contains the famous cappella Ovetari, frescoed by Andrea Mantegna, together with other frescos ascribed to Giusto de‚Äô Menabuoi and parts of frescos by Guariento. In the lower left part of the chapel of the apse you will see allegorical decorations of the five planets known to to antiquity, together with the Sun and Moon. Can you identify them?

A masterpiece of world art, the chapel was painted by Giotto between 1303 and 1305. It‚Äôs a cornucopia of charming visual inventions: a powerful place that almost overwhelms your eyes with the spiritual magic of its frescoes. These depict stories from the New and Old Testament, surmounted by the incredible blue ceiling dotted with stars. That‚Äôs where Giotto ‚Äòinvented‚Äô the comet as a pictorial subject, representing it for the first time as a ball of fire, with its long tail upwards and the brilliance of the gold tempera painting filling it with light. The inspiration? Maybe Halley‚Äôs Comet, visible in the sky when Giotto was working.

Opened in 1831, the Pedrocchi is Padua‚Äôs historical caf√©. For years, it has been the meeting point for intellectuals, professors and students. Designed by Giuseppe Jappelli, it was originally open twenty-four hours a day, and that‚Äôs why it was known as the ‚Äúcaf√© without doors‚Äù. It was at the centre of the upheavals of the Italian Risorgimento, and you can still find the hole made by an Austrian bullet during the riots. Among the various rooms of the upper floor, the Egyptian room reveals unusual attractions: a winged sun that decorates the architrave of the Egyptian-style fa√ßade and a splendid starry sky on the ceiling, maybe not Egyptian and only decorative‚Ä¶ but it doesn‚Äôt matter, it‚Äôs still beautiful!
An Egyptian sky at the heart of town

When the clock was built, civil time replaced the sun and the bells of the churches in marking out everyday activities. Its location was strategic: in the nerve centre for commercial exchanges, right next to the busiest squares crowded with people going about their everyday business, and just over from the cattle market and the place where you could rent carriages. Even today, it‚Äôs still a lively place, where you can take part in the noble art of the promenade so loved by locals, students and tourists.

Universit√† di Padova was founded in 1222, and is one of the oldest and most prestigious in the world. Also known as the Bo, because it was once the location of the inn Hospitium Bovis, it has the head of a bull as a symbol. Entering the Cortile Antico, the ancient courtyard, you‚Äôll find yourself surrounded by many coats of arms decorated by heraldic stars, in memory of illustrious students and professors. On the upper floors surrounding the courtyard, you will find the Great Hall, where Galileo gave his crowded lectures, and the Sala dei Quaranta, which preserves his chair. You can also visit the anatomical theater, the first example in the world of a permanent structure created to teach anatomy.

Seat of the town court until 1797, the Palazzo della Ragione remains the centre of public and commercial life. It is also called the Salone, because the upper floor contain a hall with an enormous loggia, decorated with a cycle of great frescoes with astrological-astronomic subjects. The ground floor hosts a typical indoor market and just outside, tables and chairs ideal if you need to take a break. Looking up, there it is: the sundial of Palazzo della Ragione, that once held a fundamental role in this commercial area.

Today an elegant area of chic boutiques, the network of streets that goes from via San Fermo to Santa Lucia was once one of the most popular areas of the town. Walking around with your head in the clouds you can find comet stars with wavy tails, hidden on the vaults of the galleries and between ancient buildings. The most illustrious of these ancient palaces looks out onto via Marsilio. It‚Äôs the house of Ezzelino, tyrant of Padua in 1200.
Stars where you least expect them

In via Santa Lucia, just next to the church, on an area originally set aside for a cemetery, you‚Äôll find the Oratorio di San Rocco. Built between 1525 and 1542, it is a charming building of great beauty. Two frescoed rooms depicting Saint Rocco‚Äôs life. As you enjoy the wonder of the place, a canopy of stars will open before you.
A starry sky for a roof

The square of the lords, so-called because the rulers of Padua, the Carraresi, lived there. It has now become the most elegant square of Padua. Its fifteenth-century elegance is framed by other prestigious buildings: the Loggia della Gran Guardia, the San Clemente church and, opposite, the palazzo del Capitanio and the Torre dell‚ÄôOrologio. The latter, designed by Jacopo Dondi, is an astronomical and astrological clock, the first in Europe. It depicts the Sun, the Moon and the planets, all moving inside a band of sky containing by the Zodiac. Curiously, instead of the usual symbol for Libra, you will find the claws of a Scorpion instead. Is it the same scorpion you find hidden on a column of the square?
Dondi‚Äôs clock and the hidden scorpion

This corner of the town is a ‚Äúsecret‚Äù place, far from traffic and the crowd, enchanting and charming. On piazzetta San Nicol√≤ sits the eponymous church, a miniature jewel, which contain frescoes, a great work of art and also a fragment of sky: the light blue canopy of stars coating the dress of the terracotta statue of the Virgin Mary, who holds the baby Jesus.

In the area right behind the Ghetto, the pavement in front of the Duomo becomes a ‚Äúsquare‚Äù for children playing and students on a short break. It hosts the Romanesque baptistery frescoed by Giusto de‚Äô Menabuoi with scenes from the Old and New Testament, the Apocalypse and the Paradise. Notice the panel representing the creation of the world, a fascinating example of how the sky and the Earth were depicted according to the astronomical and geographical knowledge of the time.

Piazza Capitaniato is familiar and elegant. It seems to invite you to stop for a break among its trees, its bicycles, the coming and going of the students. An intimate but lively place, once occupied by the Reggia dei Carraresi, the lords of Padua. The Reggia, today represented only by Sala dei Giganti and the loggia (in via Accademia), was a meeting point for intellectuals and artists, including Galileo, Petrarch and the painter Guariento. The Reggia later became the seat of the Accademia Galileiana: a prestigious institution, founded in 1599, which brought together University professors, artists and thinkers, like Galileo himself. Today, the academy is still dedicated to cultural activities.

Continuing your walk beyond the trees of piazza Capitaniato, you will reach the borders of another Padua, quiet and ancient. Enjoy via Patriarcato, and follow it to the church of San Pietro, which is almost camouflaged between the palaces of the street that bears its name. Inside you will discover two starry skies: the first, inside the great dome above the altar, depicting the four evangelists; the second, intense and encircling, in the chapel dedicated to the Black Madonna of Loreto. The altar, depicting the four evangelists; the second, intense and encircling, in the chapel dedicated to the Black Madonna of Loreto.

On Sant‚ÄôAgostino bridge ‚Äì which connects the riviera Paleocapa with piazza Castello ‚Äì you will find this little-known church, which has a mysterious charm all of its own. If you have a look inside, you can see a gloomy sky, with a celestial object. The nature and meaning of this object remain uncertain even today.

The Specola appears framed by trees, water and sky, in a corner filled with silence and beauty. Originally the tower of the Carraresi castle and even before the place where the tyrant Ezzelino locked up and tortured his prisoners, in the eighteenth century it was converted to an observatory, becoming the astronomical specula. Today it is the headquarters of the National Institute of Astrophysics and of the Museo La Specola. Inside, you will discover a universe suspended in time, a maze of vaults, stairs and corridors in which to explore the work of astronomers.
San Francesco\'s church - via San Francesco 118
Santa Sofia\'s church - via Santa Sofia 102
Palace of Ragione - piazza delle Erbe
Oratory of San Rocco - via Santa Lucia
Saint Nicol√≤\'s church - piazzetta San Nicol√≤
The Baptistery of the Cathedral - piazza Duomo
San Pietro\'s church - via San Pietro 125
San Tomaso\'s church - via San Tomaso 3
